Introduction

Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome is a potentially life-threatening drug hypersensitivity reaction that occurs 2-8 weeks after exposure.  Characteristic clinical findings include a diffuse, erythematous skin rash, fever, facial swelling, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and visceral organ dysfunction.  The diagnosis is largely clinical; treatment involves the immediate cessation of the inciting drug and supportive care (eg, fluids).  Most patients recover completely within weeks or months, but relapses may occur.

Pathogenesis



DRESS syndrome is a delayed T cell–mediated hypersensitivity reaction commonly associated with medications such as antiepileptics (eg, phenytoin), antibiotics (eg, minocycline), and allopurinol.  Unlike other drug reactions, DRESS syndrome has an unusually long latency (2-8 weeks) between drug initiation and the manifestation of symptoms.



The exact pathogenesis is unclear but likely involves a combination of metabolic, genetic, and immunologic factors that cause activation of drug-specific T lymphocytes.  These activated T cells release proinflammatory cytokines (eg, tumor necrosis factor alpha), which trigger a robust immune response that leads to inflammation, tissue injury, and necrosis across multiple organ systems, including the skin, liver, kidneys, lungs, and heart.



The complex etiology is presumed to be related to the following factors:



  • Impaired drug metabolism:  Incomplete drug detoxification (possibly due to a genetic deficiency or liver/renal dysfunction) and the subsequent accumulation of reactive metabolites can trigger an exaggerated T-cell response.
  • Genetic predisposition:  Certain variants in genes encoding drug-metabolizing enzymes (eg, cytochrome P-450) and human leukocyte antigens (HLA) may increase susceptibility.
  • Viral reactivation:  The majority of patients with DRESS syndrome also have antibody evidence of herpesvirus reactivation.  Some studies suggest cross-reactivity between herpesvirus T lymphocytes and drug antigens, causing hyperactivation of the immune system.

Risk factors



DRESS syndrome is associated with the following risk factors:



  • Medications

    • Antiepileptics (carbamazepine, phenytoin, lamotrigine).
    • Antibiotics (sulfonamides, minocycline, vancomycin).
    • Allopurinol.
  • Genetic variations in HLA and other enzymes involved in drug metabolism.
  • Reactivation of herpesviruses including HHV-6, HHV-7, cytomegalovirus (CMV), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

Clinical presentation



The onset of DRESS syndrome typically occurs several weeks after the onset of a new medication, and has a broad spectrum of clinical findings.

Systemic symptoms



  • Fever >38.5°C (101.3°F).
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy.
  • Malaise.

Physical examination



  • Diffuse morbilliform (maculopapular) rash (
    image 1
    ):  The rash starts on the face or upper trunk and can progress to diffuse, confluent erythema that typically involves >50% of body surface area.  The rash may be pruritic; plaques, follicular pustules, purpuric lesions, or exfoliative dermatitis may also develop.
  • Profound facial edema.
  • Mucosal involvement (eg, blisters) is limited, and progression to ulcerations/erosions is uncommon.

Hematologic abnormalities



  • Eosinophilia.
  • Leukocytosis.
  • Atypical lymphocytosis.

Organ involvement



Some type of visceral organ dysfunction is found in 90% of patients, which can include:



  • Liver (most common):  Hepatomegaly, jaundice, elevated alkaline phosphatase, and elevated transaminases due to hepatocyte inflammation/necrosis.
  • Kidneys:  Proteinuria, elevated creatinine, and acute renal failure due to acute interstitial nephritis.
  • Lungs:  Cough, dyspnea, and hypoxemia due to interstitial pneumonitis/pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
  • Heart (poor prognosis):  Tachycardia, chest pain, and hypotension due to eosinophilic myocarditis.
  • Other abnormalities can include pancreatitis, thyroiditis, and peripheral neuropathy.

Differential diagnosis



  • Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis (SJS/TEN) (
    image 2
    ):  A severe drug reaction characterized by painful skin necrosis and desquamation.  It typically presents with prominent mucosal erosions, which are not seen in DRESS.  SJS/TEN does not cause eosinophilia or significantly elevated liver enzymes.
  • Exanthematous drug eruption (
    image 3
    ):  Presents with a maculopapular or morbilliform rash that typically develops within 2 weeks of starting a new medication and does not involve organ dysfunction.
  • Acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (
    image 4
    ):  A skin eruption involving numerous nonfollicular pustules on an erythematous base that develops hours to days after drug exposure.  Systemic involvement can occur but is often mild.
  • Hypereosinophilic syndrome:  A condition characterized by profound eosinophilia (>1,500/mm3) and multisystem involvement (eg, heart, gastrointestinal tract, lungs, brain, skin, kidneys) but without an identifiable etiology.
  • Serum sickness–like syndrome:  Can occur after exposure to drugs (eg, antibiotics, antiepileptics) and causes systemic symptoms, arthralgias, and an urticarial or serpiginous macular rash.  However, the reaction usually occurs within 1-2 weeks of drug exposure and does not cause significant eosinophilia.
  • Hypersensitivity vasculitis:  Characterized by fever, skin findings (palpable purpura, petechiae), arthralgias, lymphadenopathy, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate.  It is frequently associated with antiepileptics but usually with no significant eosinophilia.

Diagnosis



DRESS syndrome is mainly a clinical diagnosis.  It should be considered in a patient who develops a morbilliform rash, high fever, facial swelling, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and visceral organ abnormalities several weeks after starting a new medication.  Scoring systems, such as the Registry of Severe Cutaneous Adverse Reactions (RegiSCAR), help determine the likelihood of DRESS syndrome based on the presence or absence of essential features.  Components of the RegiSCAR include:



  • Fever >38.5°C (101.3°F).
  • Enlarged lymph nodes.
  • Eosinophilia.
  • Atypical lymphocytosis.
  • Skin involvement (>50% body surface area, characteristic rash).
  • Organ involvement.
  • Resolution ≥15 days.
  • Exclusion of other potential causes.

Laboratory evaluation



The following laboratory tests are obtained to assess for the characteristic hematologic and visceral organ abnormalities associated with DRESS syndrome.



  • Complete blood count:  Eosinophilia and atypical lymphocytes are common; other abnormalities may include leukocytosis, neutrophilia, and lymphocytosis.
  • Liver function tests:  Elevated transaminases (eg, ALT, AST) and/or alkaline phosphatase indicate hepatocyte injury/necrosis.
  • Renal function tests:  Elevated creatinine indicates renal injury.
  • Cardiac enzymes:  Elevated troponin suggests myocardial injury/myocarditis.
  • Viral studies:  Evaluate for herpesvirus (eg, EBV, CMV) reactivation.
  • Autoimmune markers:  Rule out other systemic diseases that can cause rash and systemic symptoms (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus).
  • Skin biopsy:  Can confirm the diagnosis in uncertain cases.

Imaging studies



Imaging is used to further evaluate visceral organ involvement.



  • Chest x-ray/CT scan:  Evaluates for infiltrates and pleural effusions, which suggest interstitial lung injury.
  • Abdominal ultrasonography or CT scan:  Evaluates for inflammation/necrosis of intraabdominal organs.
  • Echocardiography:  Evaluates cardiac function in myocarditis or myocardial injury.

Management



The management of DRESS syndrome involves:



  • Immediate discontinuation of the offending agent.
  • Supportive care:  Antihistamines, emollients, wet dressings for pruritus/skin irritation.  Intravenous fluids for patients with hemodynamic instability, and antipyretics for fever.  Patients with severe cases may require nutritional support.
  • Corticosteroids:  Topical steroids may be used for skin irritation/pruritis in mild to moderate cases (eg, minimal or no organ dysfunction).  Systemic corticosteroids are indicated in severe cases (eg, renal failure, cardiac/lung involvement, transaminases >15x the upper limit of normal).  Steroids are continued for several weeks and gradually tapered to avoid relapse.
  • Antivirals:  Consider if herpesvirus reactivation is confirmed with PCR and the viral load is high or end organ complications are present.


Patients with organ involvement should be hospitalized for close monitoring and serial laboratory evaluations.  Mild cases may be discharged with close outpatient follow-up.

Prognosis



Clinical findings usually improve with drug cessation and supportive care, but complete resolution can take up to 6-9 weeks.



Morbidity depends on the severity and extent of internal organ involvement, and mortality can reach up to 10% in severe cases due to liver failure, myocarditis, or multiorgan dysfunction.



Relapses can occur after resolution of the acute episode.  These flare-ups may be induced by exposure to medications (other than the inciting agent) that trigger an immune response due to cross-reactivity or from repeat reactivation of herpesvirus.  Long-term sequelae may include development of autoimmune conditions such as thyroiditis, alopecia, or diabetes mellitus type 1.

Prevention



Patients should be educated about the symptoms of DRESS syndrome when starting high-risk medications and advised to seek care immediately if characteristic symptoms develop.  Patients with a history of DRESS syndrome must avoid reexposure to the causative drug and other potentially cross-reactive medications.

Summary



Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome is a severe hypersensitivity reaction that typically occurs 2-8 weeks after exposure to a drug.  Commonly implicated medications include antiepileptics, antibiotics, and allopurinol.  Patients typically develop a diffuse skin rash, fever, facial edema, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and organ dysfunction.  Treatment involves withdrawal of the offending drug and supportive care.  Most patients recover but full resolution can take several weeks.
